docs.title: What is YAML?
docs.text:
YAML (YAML Ain't Markup Language) is a human-readable data serialization language designed for data exchange between languages with different data structures.

It's often used for configuration files, data exchange, and representing complex data structures in a readable format.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Human Readable - Easy to read and write for both humans and machines
  • Language Independent - Works across programming languages and platforms
  • Hierarchical - Supports complex nested data structures
  • Extensible - Can be extended with custom data types
  • Secure - Built with security considerations in mind

docs.title: History
docs.text:
YAML was first proposed by Clark Evans in 2001, and was designed together with Ingy döt Net and Oren Ben-Kiki.

The name "YAML" is a recursive acronym for "YAML Ain't Markup Language", emphasizing that YAML is primarily a data serialization language rather than a markup language.

docs.title: Infrastructure as Code
docs.text: YAML is the de facto standard for defining infrastructure configurations in tools like Kubernetes, Docker Compose, and Terraform.

docs.title: DevOps and CI/CD
docs.text: Modern CI/CD pipelines rely heavily on YAML for defining build steps, deployment configurations, and automation workflows.

docs.title: Cloud-Native Applications
docs.text: As organizations move to cloud-native architectures, YAML becomes increasingly critical for managing complex distributed systems.

docs.title: Configuration Management
docs.text: YAML provides a clean, readable way to manage application configurations across different environments and deployment stages.

docs.title: YAML in the Enterprise
docs.text:
Large enterprises depend on YAML for:

  • Kubernetes Deployments - Managing thousands of containers
  • Microservices Configuration - Service discovery and configuration
  • Security Policies - Access control and compliance rules
  • Monitoring and Alerting - Observability stack configuration
  • Data Pipeline Definitions - ETL and data processing workflows

docs.title: YAML 1.2
docs.text:

Key features: - Human-readable data serialization - Language-independent data structures - Hierarchical data representation - Extensible data types - Security-focused design

docs.title: Next-Generation YAML
docs.text: YAMLScript is the future of YAML, extending the language with powerful programming capabilities while maintaining backward compatibility with existing YAML 1.2.

docs.title: What is YAMLScript?
docs.text: YAMLScript is a superset of YAML that adds programming language features to the familiar YAML syntax, enabling you to write executable YAML documents.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Backward Compatible - All existing YAML 1.2 documents work unchanged
  • Programming Capabilities - Functions, variables, loops, and conditionals
  • Data Processing - Transform and manipulate YAML data programmatically
  • Template System - Generate dynamic YAML content
  • Performance - Optimized execution for large documents

docs.title: Current Limitations
docs.text:
Traditional YAML has limitations for complex use cases:

  • Static Content - No dynamic generation capabilities
  • Repetition - Manual duplication of similar structures
  • Validation - Limited runtime validation and transformation
  • Integration - Difficult to integrate with external data sources

docs.title: YAMLScript Solutions
docs.text:
YAMLScript addresses these limitations:

  • Dynamic Generation - Create YAML content programmatically
  • DRY Principle - Eliminate repetition through functions and loops
  • Runtime Validation - Validate and transform data at execution time
  • External Integration - Connect to databases, APIs, and services

docs.title: Infrastructure as Code
docs.text:
Generate complex Kubernetes configurations dynamically:

# Generate multiple similar deployments
deployments:
  for service in services:
    - apiVersion: apps/v1
      kind: Deployment
      metadata:
        name: ${service.name}
        labels:
          app: ${service.name}
      spec:
        replicas: ${service.replicas}
        selector:
          matchLabels:
            app: ${service.name}

docs.title: Configuration Management
docs.text:
Create dynamic application configurations:

# Environment-specific configuration
config:
  database:
    host: ${env.DB_HOST}
    port: ${env.DB_PORT}
    credentials: ${load_secrets('db')}

  features:
    for feature in features:
      ${feature.name}: ${feature.enabled}

docs.title: Data Processing
docs.text:
Transform and validate YAML data:

# Process and validate user input
users:
  for user in input_users:
    if validate_user(user):
      - name: ${user.name}
        email: ${user.email}
        role: ${determine_role(user.permissions)}

docs.title: Variables and Expressions
docs.text:
# Define and use variables
vars:
  company_name: "Acme Corp"
  api_version: "v1"

config:
  company: ${company_name}
  version: ${api_version}
  timestamp: ${now()}

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
# Define reusable functions
functions:
  generate_id: |
    function(name, type) {
      return "${type}_${name}_${uuid()}"
    }

  validate_email: |
    function(email) {
      return email.matches(/^[^@]+@[^@]+\.[^@]+$/)
    }

docs.title: Control Flow
docs.text:
# Conditional and loop constructs
services:
  for service in service_list:
    if service.enabled:
      - name: ${service.name}
        config: ${service.config}
    else:
      - name: ${service.name}
        status: "disabled"

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
# Robust error handling
try:
  config: ${load_config()}
catch error:
  config: ${default_config()}
  log: "Failed to load config: ${error.message}"

docs.title: Risk Assessment
docs.text:
What happens if YAML fails in your infrastructure?

  • Production Outages - Kubernetes deployments fail, services go down
  • Security Breaches - Vulnerabilities in YAML parsers exploited
  • Development Delays - CI/CD pipelines break, releases blocked
  • Compliance Issues - Security and audit requirements not met
  • Customer Impact - Service disruptions affect user experience

docs.title: Dependency Analysis
docs.text:
How critical is YAML to your operations?

  • Kubernetes Clusters - Every pod, service, and configuration
  • CI/CD Pipelines - Build, test, and deployment automation
  • Application Configs - Environment variables and settings
  • Infrastructure as Code - Terraform, Ansible, and cloud configs
  • API Definitions - OpenAPI/Swagger specifications
